image.altText: A photo of a woman laughing in a hospital bed with her son and daughter next to her

props.synopsis: The former nurse was diagnosed with an aggressive form of motor neurone disease and given months to live. Her dying wish was to save lives — and she did in an Australian first.

title.children: Minutes before she died, Ballarat nurse Marlene found out she would save four lives

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall sit, surrounded by their children, all the women holding bouquets

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch always wanted his media empire to stay in the family, but he could never commit to an heir. Despite having six children, only three were ever considered viable successors.

title.children: With Rupert Murdoch going, his children have a chessboard of potential moves to make

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch gestures with both hands while speaking.

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch's retirement is a momentous media moment that could lead to big shifts in the media and political landscapes in Australia and other parts of the English-speaking world.

title.children: The world's biggest press baron is handing over power. How will it affect media in Australia and abroad?

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks at a podium at the National Press Club

props.synopsis: No campaigner Jacinta Nampijinpa Price told the National Press Club last week there are no ongoing negative impacts of colonisation on Indigenous Australians. RMIT ABC Fact Check takes a look.

title.children: We fact checked Jacinta Nampijinpa Price on the negative impacts of colonisation. Here's what we found

image.altText: A ribbon bound version of Australia's constitution with a photo of the Australian outback in the background.

props.synopsis: Australia will vote on whether to make a change to its constitution next month. But what is this document? And what is the proposed change? We break it down for you here, and show you what the constitution would look like if the Voice referendum is passed.

title.children: Here's how the Australian Constitution would change if the Voice referendum is passed

image.altText: a woman in front of a sold sign out the front of an apartment block with a real estate agent

props.synopsis: Almost one in six sellers in Sydney's high-construction neighbourhoods are losing money, some as much as $100,000 for their lifetime investment, with interest rate squeeze pushing buyers to sell up for a loss.

title.children: Ella's story of selling a Sydney unit for a $90,000 loss will make you think twice about entering the housing market

image.altText: A woman holds her stomach which has a baby in it and leans on a tree.

props.synopsis: Working full-time, recently married and pregnant, Maria and her partner never thought they wouldn't be able to find a home. But amid the rental crisis that's plaguing Australia, living in a tent was their only option.

title.children: Priced out of the rental market and six months pregnant, Maria's only option was to live in a tent

image.altText: A man in traditional Indian costume, makeup and jewelry performs a dance move on stage.

props.synopsis: An iconic inner-city Melbourne dance school celebrates its 50th birthday — with innovator and artist Dr Chandrabhanu OAM at its helm.

title.children: 'He made us proud of our identity': How one teacher founded an epic 50-year legacy of Indian dance

image.altText: Zelenskyy standing with US senators.

props.synopsis: After seeking to shore up international support at the United Nations, Mr Zelenskyy comes to Washington on a crosstown blitz including meetings with military leaders and Mr Biden and an evening address at the National Archives museum.

title.children: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy faces tough crowd in US as Biden approves half a billion in military aid

image.altText: Lachlan Murdoch and Rupert Murdoch sitting together at Day 10 of the US Open held at the USTA Tennis Center on September 5, 2018

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Malcolm Turnbull says Lachlan Murdoch is 'more ideological than his father', King Charles visits fire-damaged Notre-Dame. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Richmond football coach Adem Yze wants his players to push for the top four next year. The 46-year-old was unveiled today as the new Tigers coach, after narrowly beating interim coach Andrew McQualter to the job. Yze has tasted premiership success as an assistant coach with both Hawthorn and Melbourne. He says he wasn't deterred from applying for the Richmond position, despite missing out on several senior coaching jobs including Essendon and the Giants last year. “We‘re not going to put a ceiling on where we can finish,” Yze says. “I get huge upside watching what other teams have done … not to say that that’s what we’re going to do but that’s what we’re going to strive to do. “I want our players walking into the footy club thinking that they can make the top four next year. We won’t put a ceiling on it. “There might be some bumps along the road and as a footy club we’ll be really strong during that period. Can’t wait to get started.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Richmond coach says Tigers will strive for top four in 2024

children.content: (Getty Images: Dylan Burns)
New Richmond football coach Adem Yze wants his players to push for the top four next year.
The 46-year-old was unveiled today as the new Tigers coach, after narrowly beating interim coach Andrew McQualter to the job.
Yze has tasted premiership success as an assistant coach with both Hawthorn and Melbourne.
He says he wasn't deterred from applying for the Richmond position, despite missing out on several senior coaching jobs including Essendon and the Giants last year.
“We‘re not going to put a ceiling on where we can finish,” Yze says.
“I get huge upside watching what other teams have done … not to say that that’s what we’re going to do but that’s what we’re going to strive to do.
“I want our players walking into the footy club thinking that they can make the top four next year. We won’t put a ceiling on it.
“There might be some bumps along the road and as a footy club we’ll be really strong during that period. Can’t wait to get started.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here is the full memo media mogul Rupert Murdoch has sent to News Corp staff as he steps down: Dear Colleagues, I am writing to let you all know that I have decided to transition to the role of Chairman Emeritus at Fox and News. For my entire professional life, I have been engaged daily with news and ideas, and that will not change. But the time is right for me to take on different roles, knowing that we have truly talented teams and a passionate, principled leader in Lachlan who will become sole Chairman of both companies. Neither excessive pride nor false humility are admirable qualities. But I am truly proud of what we have achieved collectively through the decades, and I owe much to my colleagues, whose contributions to our success have sometimes been unseen outside the company but are deeply appreciated by me. Whether the truck drivers distributing our papers, the cleaners who toil when we have left the office, the assistants who support us or the skilled operators behind the cameras or the computer code, we would be less successful and have less positive impact on society without your day-after-day dedication. Our companies are in robust health, as am I. Our opportunities far exceed our commercial challenges. We have every reason to be optimistic about the coming years - I certainly am, and plan to be here to participate in them. But the battle for the freedom of speech and, ultimately, the freedom of thought, has never been more intense. My father firmly believed in freedom, and Lachlan is absolutely committed to the cause. Self-serving bureaucracies are seeking to silence those who would question their provenance and purpose. Elites have open contempt for those who are not members of their rarefied class. Most of the media is in cahoots with those elites, peddling political narratives rather than pursuing the truth. In my new role, I can guarantee you that I will be involved every day in the contest of ideas. Our companies are communities, and I will be an active member of our community. I will be watching our broadcasts with a critical eye, reading our newspapers and websites and books with much interest, and reaching out to you with thoughts, ideas, and advice. When I visit your countries and companies, you can expect to see me in the office late on a Friday afternoon. I look forward to seeing you wherever you work and whatever your responsibility. And I urge you to make the most of this great opportunity to improve the world we live in.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rupert Murdoch says in letter to staff he's in 'robust health'

children.content: Here is the full memo media mogul Rupert Murdoch has sent to News Corp staff as he steps down:
Dear Colleagues,

I am writing to let you all know that I have decided to transition to the role of Chairman Emeritus at Fox and News. For my entire professional life, I have been engaged daily with news and ideas, and that will not change. But the time is right for me to take on different roles, knowing that we have truly talented teams and a passionate, principled leader in Lachlan who will become sole Chairman of both companies.

Neither excessive pride nor false humility are admirable qualities. But I am truly proud of what we have achieved collectively through the decades, and I owe much to my colleagues, whose contributions to our success have sometimes been unseen outside the company but are deeply appreciated by me. Whether the truck drivers distributing our papers, the cleaners who toil when we have left the office, the assistants who support us or the skilled operators behind the cameras or the computer code, we would be less successful and have less positive impact on society without your day-after-day dedication.

Our companies are in robust health, as am I. Our opportunities far exceed our commercial challenges. We have every reason to be optimistic about the coming years - I certainly am, and plan to be here to participate in them. But the battle for the freedom of speech and, ultimately, the freedom of thought, has never been more intense.

My father firmly believed in freedom, and Lachlan is absolutely committed to the cause. Self-serving bureaucracies are seeking to silence those who would question their provenance and purpose. Elites have open contempt for those who are not members of their rarefied class. Most of the media is in cahoots with those elites, peddling political narratives rather than pursuing the truth.

In my new role, I can guarantee you that I will be involved every day in the contest of ideas. Our companies are communities, and I will be an active member of our community. I will be watching our broadcasts with a critical eye, reading our newspapers and websites and books with much interest, and reaching out to you with thoughts, ideas, and advice. When I visit your countries and companies, you can expect to see me in the office late on a Friday afternoon.
I look forward to seeing you wherever you work and whatever your responsibility. And I urge you to make the most of this great opportunity to improve the world we live in.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Electoral Commission says a record number of young and Indigenous Australians have enrolled to vote in the upcoming referendum. Figures from the AEC reveal almost 98 per cent of eligible Australians have registered to vote in the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum next month. A Voice to Parliament would act as an independent advisory body for First Nations people. Australian Electoral Commissioner, Tom Rogers, says the registration figures are a great result. "It's criticial that all Australians have their chance to have their say," he says. "Youth enrolment is at the highest rate its ever been for an electoral event and the same for estimated indigenous enrolment so it's a great outcome for all Australians and it means that it will be a solid event and a solid outcome." Rogers says the referendum vote is a huge logistical event. "We'll be visiting well over 750 remote communities. I think last week we dispatched 160,000 ballot papers to our overseas missions - the largest in-person overseas vote that we've seen. "Big postal process is underway. I think as of yesterday we've had something like about 1.2 million applications for postal votes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Record number of Australians enrol to vote in Voice referendum

children.content: The Australian Electoral Commission says a record number of young and Indigenous Australians have enrolled to vote in the upcoming referendum.
Figures from the AEC reveal almost 98 per cent of eligible Australians have registered to vote in the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum next month.
A Voice to Parliament would act as an independent advisory body for First Nations people.
Australian Electoral Commissioner, Tom Rogers, says the registration figures are a great result.
"It's criticial that all Australians have their chance to have their say," he says.

"Youth enrolment is at the highest rate its ever been for an electoral event and the same for estimated indigenous enrolment so it's a great outcome for all Australians and it means that it will be a solid event and a solid outcome."
Rogers says the referendum vote is a huge logistical event.
"We'll be visiting well over 750 remote communities. I think last week we dispatched 160,000 ballot papers to our overseas missions - the largest in-person overseas vote that we've seen.
"Big postal process is underway. I think as of yesterday we've had something like about 1.2 million applications for postal votes."

image.altText: Workers in high-vis cloths work in a hole in the street.

props.synopsis: A leak that saw gas "spewing" through an inner-Launceston suburb is fixed and roads reopened.

title.children: Gas leak fixed after sparking emergency evacuation of Launceston homes

image.altText: Actor Angus cloud in a black-and-white photograph.

props.synopsis: Actor Angus Cloud, best known for his role in Euphoria, died from an accidental overdose of cocaine, fentanyl and other substances, a Northern California coroner's office said.

title.children: Euphoria actor Angus Cloud died of accidental overdose, coroner says

image.altText: Dark MOFO's winter feast 2015

props.synopsis: Hobart's popular winter tourist drawcard, Dark Mofo, is cancelled for 2024, but two festival staples — the Winter Fest and Nude Solstice Swim — will still go ahead.

title.children: Hobart's Dark Mofo cancelled for 2024 to allow for 'period of renewal'

image.altText: Jim Chalmers pointing during a press conference.

props.synopsis: The federal government has revealed the country's first surplus in 15 years as the final budget outcome figures for the last year show a surplus of over $22 billion.

title.children: Government reveals first budget surplus in 15 years, $22 billion in pot

image.altText: Russell Brand is pictured singing with a microphone in his hand.

props.synopsis: The woman tells the BBC the comedian exposed himself to her in 2008 when she was working in the same building as the BBC in Los Angeles.

title.children: Woman tells BBC Russell Brand exposed himself to her and laughed about it on the radio

image.altText: An illustrated image of Norman Bates with half his face as an android

props.synopsis: Five years after researchers created a psychopathic algorithm to demonstrate bias and discrimination in artificial intelligence, we're still learning its lessons.

title.children: An AI experiment named after an Alfred Hitchcock psycho started as a joke. It turned into a warning

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch gestures in front of a sign that reads "Fox"

props.synopsis: Australia's share market slumps after losses on Wall Street overnight, while Rupert Murdoch has stepped down as Fox chairman.

title.children: ASX falls sharply, Rupert Murdoch steps down as Fox chairman, Wall Street closes at lowest since June

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The new CEO of Qantas Vanessa Hudson has make a public apology saying the airline has let the customers down and will try to rebuild the trust. "We understand why you’re frustrated and why some of you have lost trust in us," she said in a video message to customers. "I know that our people have tried their absolute best under very difficult circumstances. "I want you to know that we’re determined to fix it. "We want to get back to being  the national carrier that all Australians can be proud of. That’s known for going above and beyond." Ms Hudson said the company will hire more people in its call centres, add more frequent flyer seats, review all of its customer policies, and give the frontline teams more flexibility.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We have let you down': Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson apologies

children.content: The new CEO of Qantas Vanessa Hudson has make a public apology saying the airline has let the customers down and will try to rebuild the trust.
"We understand why you’re frustrated and why some of you have lost trust in us," she said in a video message to customers.
"I know that our people have tried their absolute best under very difficult circumstances.
"I want you to know that we’re determined to fix it.
"We want to get back to being  the national carrier that all Australians can be proud of. That’s known for going above and beyond."
Ms Hudson said the company will hire more people in its call centres,
add more frequent flyer seats, review all of its customer policies, and give the frontline teams more flexibility.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Following a Fair Work Commission recommendation today, a spokesperson from Chevron Australia has told the ABC: Chevron Australia has consistently engaged in meaningful negotiations in an effort to finalise enterprise agreements with market-competitive remuneration and conditions. Today, we were provided a recommendation from Commissioner Riordan. After considering the recommendation, Chevron has accepted the recommendation to resolve all outstanding issues and finalise the agreements. We have informed the commissioner of our position and written to the unions and other employee bargaining representatives confirming our acceptance.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: And here's the response from Chevron Australia

children.content: Following a Fair Work Commission recommendation today, a spokesperson from Chevron Australia has told the ABC:
Chevron Australia has consistently engaged in meaningful negotiations in an effort to finalise enterprise agreements with market-competitive remuneration and conditions.
Today, we were provided a recommendation from Commissioner Riordan.
After considering the recommendation, Chevron has accepted the recommendation to resolve all outstanding issues and finalise the agreements.
We have informed the commissioner of our position and written to the unions and other employee bargaining representatives confirming our acceptance.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Offshore Alliance members at Chevron have endorsed a recommendation put by the Fair Work Commission at a late-night mass meeting of more than 350 workers. Offshore Alliance members from three Chevron gas facilities — Gorgon, Wheatstone Platform and Wheatstone Downstream — met at 7pm WA time to consider a recommendation put to both Chevron and Offshore Alliance members yesterday morning by Commissioner Riordan. The proposed enterprise agreements, which incorporate the commissioner's recommendations, contain substantial improvements in terms and conditions of employment including increased remuneration, job security, locked-in rosters, career progression and returning all employees to a 40 per cent roster. The Offshore Alliance will now work with Chevron to finalise the drafting of the three agreements and members will soon cease current industrial action. The Offshore Alliance is an alliance between The Australian Workers’ Union (AWU) and the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA). Offshore Alliance spokesperson, AWU WA secretary Brad Gandy, says Offshore Alliance members carefully considered Commissioner Riordan’s recommendation before endorsing it. “Commissioner Riordan’s recommendation contains substantial improvements in terms and conditions of employment, including increased remuneration, job security, locked-in rosters, career progression and returning all employees to a 40 per cent roster,” Mr Gandy says. “'The Offshore Alliance is a member-led union and at a late-night mass meeting members endorsed the latest offer, which incorporates the Fair Work Commission's recommendations. “The Offshore Alliance will now work with Chevron to finalise the drafting of the agreement and members will soon cease current industrial action."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Offshore Alliance members at Chevron endorse Fair Work Commission recommendation

children.content: Offshore Alliance members at Chevron have endorsed a recommendation put by the Fair Work Commission at a late-night mass meeting of more than 350 workers.

Offshore Alliance members from three Chevron gas facilities — Gorgon, Wheatstone Platform and Wheatstone Downstream — met at 7pm WA time to consider a recommendation put to both Chevron and Offshore Alliance members yesterday morning by Commissioner Riordan.
The proposed enterprise agreements, which incorporate the commissioner's recommendations,

contain substantial improvements in terms and conditions of employment including increased remuneration, job security, locked-in rosters, career progression and returning all employees to a 40 per cent roster.
The Offshore Alliance will now work with Chevron to finalise the drafting of the three agreements and members will soon cease current industrial action.
The Offshore Alliance is an alliance between The Australian Workers’ Union (AWU) and the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA).
Offshore Alliance spokesperson, AWU WA secretary Brad Gandy, says Offshore Alliance members carefully considered Commissioner Riordan’s recommendation before endorsing it.

“Commissioner Riordan’s recommendation contains substantial improvements in terms and conditions of employment, including increased remuneration, job security, locked-in rosters, career progression and returning all employees to a 40 per cent roster,” Mr Gandy says.
“'The Offshore Alliance is a member-led union and at a late-night mass meeting members endorsed the latest offer, which incorporates the Fair Work Commission's recommendations.
“The Offshore Alliance will now work with Chevron to finalise the drafting of the agreement and members will soon cease current industrial action."

image.altText: Police, ambulance and fire services attend the scene of a fatal crash

props.synopsis: The driver of the allegedly stolen ute was tracked down by police dogs in a drain 4 kilometres away.

title.children: Dog squad tracks down man in drain after he flees scene of fatal crash north of Brisbane

image.altText: A child wears a facemask and steers a boat on the water with the red-orange sky behind them.

props.synopsis: For the first time in three years, Australians face the risk of significant bushfires. Are we any better prepared for big fires than we were before Black Summer?

title.children: Australia has had four years to learn from Black Summer. Are we better prepared for this fire season?

image.altText: A blurred out image of a male prisoner in the foreground, with cow calves in the background.

props.synopsis: As the country's dairy industry battles labour shortages, a West Australian prison is working to help fill those gaps by training workers behind bars.

title.children: How milking cows and raising calves is setting these prisoners up to re-enter the community

image.altText: A Collingwood AFL player pumps his fists as he celebrates a goal.

props.synopsis: After being sidelined with injury since early August, Nick Daicos is included in Collingwood's line-up for the grand final qualifier, as GWS prepares to contain the young Magpies star.

title.children: Giants aim to 'minimise the damage' as Daicos makes Magpies return in preliminary final

image.altText: A coach speaks to Melbourne AFL players during a 2023 premiership match.

props.synopsis: Richmond opts for one of the most experienced assistants in the AFL as it finally fills the role vacated by three-time premiership coach Damien Hardwick.

title.children: 'A great fit for the club': Tigers throw support behind Hardwick's long-term successor

image.altText: A black and white photo of an unseen woman holding up a hand to protect herself.

props.synopsis: The Supreme Court gives NSW Police extraordinary powers to recover and relocate an at-risk teenager by flying her to a safe house in Sydney.

title.children: Welfare officials considered the risk of harm to 16yo 'Emma' so great, they asked to charter a plane to rescue her

image.altText: A sign adorns the building where mining company Rio Tinto has their office in Perth, Western Australia, November 19, 2015.

props.synopsis: Mining giant Rio Tinto says it has apologised to traditional owners after a blast at one of its operations in WA's Pilbara caused damage to an ancient heritage site.

title.children: Three years after Juukan Gorge disaster, Rio Tinto blast damages ancient rock shelter

image.altText: An aerial image of a power station with white towers and steam, against a blue-pink horizon.

props.synopsis: A high-stakes fight over the future of a failed Australian coal mine descends into acrimony, as a major power station takes legal action against consultancy Deloitte.

title.children: Power fight turns nasty as US-controlled plant decries efforts to 'destroy' its rights

image.altText: Wind farms at dusk with the sun setting behind them on the coast line

props.synopsis: The debate still rages about dealing with climate change and, close to home, Australia's energy transition, which is under way but accompanied by increasing pain and problems, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Albanese government faces an uphill road and angry locals as it drives change to renewables

image.altText: An anxious-looking black Labrador curled up on a couch with a zebra-striped blanket.

props.synopsis: There's growing recognition that animals can develop mental and behavioural disorders like humans, but there are important factors to consider when treating these issues.

title.children: Prozac has helped Brian the labrador's anxiety. But treating pets' mental health can be complicated

image.altText: Imran Khan walks through a dense crowd of men as he tries to leave a courtroom while wearing sunglasses.

props.synopsis: As former Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan languishes in a jail cell near Islamabad and his supporters fall silent in fear, his family welcomed the ABC inside his heavily guarded home in Lahore.

title.children: Imran Khan was rich, famous and powerful. Now he’s in a tiny, filthy prison cell in Pakistan

image.altText: An over/under photo of Brett Connellan, shirtless and sitting on a surfboard in the ocean.

props.synopsis: Two men who have faced significant challenges are helping school students better navigate the setbacks they will have in life.

title.children: From a shark attack to bleeding lungs, these survivors are teaching high school students about resilience

image.altText: two photos side by side, one of a boy in hospital with his head patched up and the same boy in a wetsuit and helmet at the beach

props.synopsis: Ted Badgery never wore a helmet in the ocean until recently. Now, he rarely surfs without one.

title.children: Surfing is one of the only extreme sports where helmets are rarely worn — but that's starting to change

image.altText: A young man in an orange cap, at night, talking to media, with reflective light obscuring his face.

props.synopsis: Oscar Piastri is 11th in the drivers' championship, with six top 10 finishes and a best of fourth at the British Grand Prix.

title.children: Armed with upgrades and a new contract, Piastri sets sights on Japan

image.altText: A woman on a train films herself

props.synopsis: A few weeks ago Sabrina Bahsoon could travel on London's public transport system without being noticed, but in just a few short weeks she's become "Tube Girl", whose self-shot dancing videos on her commute have sparked a viral social media trend.

title.children: Who is 'Tube Girl'? How a viral sensation is sparking conversations about self-confidence
